results.title: Friendship beats the storm
results.creator_credit: Eliza Goldsmith, Kiera Chapman, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Best friends Kiera Chapman and Eliza Goldsmith have been through quite a lot together. When Chapman’s family took shelter during the torando that hit Lennox Head in 2010, Goldsmith cut her feet running over to see if Chapman was ok. As they weathered the storm together, they share the experience with their family, community and with each other.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eliza Goldsmith, Kiera Chapman, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Force of the wind
results.creator_credit: Justin Somerville, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Justin Somerville never thought he would be in the middle of a tornado, so his first reaction was that he wanted to witness this phenomena. His account of the aftermath provides detail well beyond the media coverage of the devestation of this small town.
On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado.

results.title: A Disastrous day
results.creator_credit: Abby Dietrich, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: It was a typical morning in Lennox Head for Abby Dietrich and her mother, when things changed dramatically. A tornado and intense storm were followed by calls from friends and family, and the community checking up on each other, helping out and cleaning up.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Abby Dietrich, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Big, grey and tubey
results.creator_credit: Sage Armstrong, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
When the tornado hit, Sage Armstrong and her mother took shelter in the toilet. Traumatised by the experience, Armstrong was able to find solace in helping others in the aftermath.
On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado.

results.title: The Big roar
results.creator_credit: Daniel Young, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Daniel Young didn’t feel safe the night before the tornado roared through his house. After it had passed, Young’s family were safe but it had left a great wave of destruction in its path.

On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado.

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2010]
results.brief_description: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.
results.title_for_label: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2010]
results.description: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.

results.title: An Interview with Laurie Price
results.creator_credit: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Laurie Price is one of the remaining third of those Australians who served in Korea. He provides sharp detail of the work he performed there on the airfields, the distractions and tensions, even between allies. While the war is long over, it continues to affect Price even today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Interview with John Balloch
results.brief_description: John Balloch was at school when war was declared. Even so, he couldn’t wait to sign up. He wanted to be a fighter pilot, flying alone. He tells of his training and time serving in the RAAF during World War II and pays tribute to those lost, both to the enemy and accidents.

results.title: An Interview with Jan McCarthy
results.brief_description: Jan McCarthy traces her career path of nursing, how it took her overseas and her time in the army, posted in Vietnam and Singapore. In Singapore, McCarthy became a Major and was later promoted to Colonel. She has no regrets about serving in the army and sees it as one big family.
results.description: Jan McCarthy traces her career path of nursing, how it took her overseas and her time in the army, posted in Vietnam and Singapore. In Singapore, McCarthy became a Major and was later promoted to Colonel. She has no regrets about serving in the army and sees it as one big family.

results.title: An Interview with Jack Jones
results.brief_description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.
